questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for gallbladder cancer?
questions.explanation:
Risk Factors For Carcinoma GB

Gallstones:
  • 90% of carcinoma cases are associated with gallstones.
  • The risk of developing carcinoma in gallstone disease is 7-10 times higher than in the general population.
  • Relative risk based on stone size:
  • Less than 2 cm: Lower risk
  • 2-3 cm: Relative risk of 2.5
  • More than 3 cm (Option D): Relative risk of 10 or more

Other Conditions:
  • Choledochal cyst
  • Anomalous pancreaticobiliary duct junction (20%)
  • Gallbladder polyps (more than 1 cm in size, more than 3 in number, or adenomatous polyps)
  • Porcelain gallbladder (Option A): 25% risk of malignant transformation, with 90% being inoperable tumours
  • Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (Option B)

Infections and Inflammatory Conditions:
  • Chronic typhoid carriers
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Hepatitis B and hepatitis C virus infections

Other factors:
  • Polypoid lesions (GB polyp)
  • Xanthogranulomatous cholecystitis
  • Nitrosamines
  • Carcinogens

questions.text: Post-orchidectomy, the specimen shows Reinke's Crystals. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Leydig cell tumour

Sertoli cell tumour

Hormonal involvement

It often involves androgens, oestrogens, and corticosteroids.

Hormonally silent.

Conditions associated with
  • Klinefelter syndrome.
  • Cryptorchidism.
  • Renal cell carcinoma.
  • Carney complex.
  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome.
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis.

Malignancy

10% (in adults)

10%

Gross
  • Circumscribed nodules, usually < 5 cm in diameter.
  • They have a distinctive golden brown, homogeneous appearance on cut surfaces.

Firm, small nodules with a homogeneous

grey-white to yellow cut surface.

 

Histology
  • The tumour cells resemble their normal counterparts.
  • They are large in size and have round or polygonal cell outlines, abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm, and a round central nucleus.
  • The cytoplasm frequently contains lipid droplets, vacuoles, or lipofuscin pigment and, most characteristically, rod-shaped Reinke crystalloids (25% of the tumours).
  • The tumour cells are arranged in distinctive trabeculae that tend to form cord-like structures and tubules.

 

Image

Key Features

CFTR Defect

questions.text: The diagram displays nerve cell physiology. The event marked by 3 to 4 is due to _______ ?
Which of the following describes an aortic regurgitation murmur?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Diastolic murmur

Murmur Type

Subtype

Conditions murmur heard

Additional points

Systolic Murmurs

Ejection Systolic Murmur

(HAPpy)
  1. Pulmonary Stenosis
  2. Aortic Stenosis
  3. HOCM
  • Early systolic murmur seen with papillary muscle dysfunction.
  • Late systolic murmur is seen in small VSD and mitral valve prolapse (MVP)

Pan Systolic Murmur(MTV)
  1. Mitral regurgitation
  2. Tricuspid regurgitation
  3. Ventricular septal defect

Diastolic Murmurs

Early Diastolic Murmur (GAP)
  1. Graham Steell murmur
  2. Aortic regurgitation
  3. Pulmonary regurgitation (mild)
  • Along with hemodynamic changes the characteristics of flow also changes

Mid-Diastolic Murmur
  1. Carey Coombs murmur
  2. Austin Flint murmur
  3. Mitral stenosis
  • Flow murmur may mimic mid-diastolic murmur

Continuous Murmurs

 
  1. Patent ductus arteriosus
  2. Aortopulmonary window
  3. Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm
  4. Coronary arteriovenous fistula
  5. Cervical venous hum
  6. Anomalous left coronary artery origin
  7. Mammary souffle of pregnancy
  8. Bronchial collateral circulation
  9. Intercostal or pulmonary arteriovenous fistula
  10. Peripheral pulmonic stenosis
  • Causes are diverse and involve persistent communication between systemic and pulmonary circulation.

Examination Findings of Aortic Regurgitation

Blood Pressure
  • Elevated systolic pressure and decreased diastolic pressure result in increased arterial pulse pressure.
  • Atrio-ventricular malformation and Atrio-ventricular ﬁstula also show low diastolic BP due to continuous Korotkoﬀ sounds.
  • Positive Hill’s sign is an abnormal difference in BP in the upper limb and lower limb.

On Palpation
  • Heaving LV impulse is noted, which is displaced laterally and inferiorly
  • Diastolic and Systolic Thrills were noticed at the left lower sternal border and suprasternal notch, respectively.

On Auscultation

 

Heart Sounds
  • A2 is absent
  • In the Bicuspid aortic valve, systolic ejection sound is present
  • Sometimes, A4 is also heard

 

 

 

 

 

 

Murmurs
  • A Decrescendo diastolic murmur, best heard when sitting up and leaning forward, is an early diastolic murmur that becomes holo-diastolic as the condition progresses to a severe stage.
  • Musical diastolic murmur is aortic cusp fluttering in the regurgitant flow.
  • Mid-diastolic murmur
  • Austin Flint murmur is a soft, low-pitched, mid- to end-diastolic murmur caused by mitral valve displacement due to AR.
  • Ejection systolic murmur is commonly heard in AR along with AS.

questions.text: What is the enzyme deficiency in Pompe’s disease?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase

Pompe disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type II)

Definition

Glycogen storage disorder caused by deficiency of acid α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase)

Inheritance

Autosomal recessive

 

Pathophysiology

Accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes, primarily affecting cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells

 

Forms
  • Infantile Pompe disease (IPD) - Severe
  • Late-onset Pompe disease (LOPD) - Less Severe

Clinical Features
  • IPD: Hypotonia, muscle weakness, feeding difficulties, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
  • LOPD: Proximal limb-girdle muscle weakness, respiratory muscle involvement, cardiac rhythm disturbances

 

Laboratory Findings
  • Elevated serum CK, AST, ALT, LDH
  • Cardiomegaly on chest X-ray (infantile form)
  • ECG changes- shortened P-R interval, tall QRS complexes

Treatment
  • Enzyme replacement therapy with alglucosidase alfa
  • High-protein diet (for LOPD)

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a complication of blood transfusion in a 25-year-old mother who developed acute postpartum haemorrhage (PPH), hypovolemic shock, and underwent major blood transfusion after delivering a baby boy?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Hypokalemia

Complication

Cause

Effect

Prevention/ Management

Hypothermia (Option C)

Transfusion of cold blood (stored at 4°C).

Body temperature drops, leading to impaired clotting mechanisms (coagulopathy), and worsening bleeding.
  • Warm blood products before transfusion
  • Use external warming methods (e.g., warming blankets).

Coagulopathy

Dilution of clotting factors and platelets due to transfusion; consumption of clotting factors by ongoing haemorrhage.

Impaired blood clotting, prolonged bleeding time, increased risk of continued bleeding.
  • Administer fresh frozen plasma (FFP), platelets, and cryoprecipitate.
  • For massive BT, blood products should be administered in a 1:1:1 ratio.
  • Monitor clotting factors (e.g., PT, aPTT).

Citrate Toxicity

Large volumes of transfused blood contain citrate, which binds to calcium.

Hypocalcemia (Option A), leads to muscle cramps, seizures, and cardiac arrhythmias.

Administer calcium gluconate or calcium chloride prophylactically.

Hyperkalemia (Option D)

Potassium leaks from stored red blood cells into plasma during storage.

Elevated potassium levels (hyperkalemia) can cause cardiac arrhythmias, potentially leading to cardiac arrest.
  • Monitor potassium levels.
  • Administer calcium to stabilize the myocardium.
  • Insulin with glucose to shift potassium intracellularly if needed.

Metabolic Alkalosis

Rapid metabolism of citrate into bicarbonate.

Increased pH (alkalosis) can lead to muscle twitching, irritability, and impaired oxygen release from haemoglobin.
  • Monitor arterial blood gases (ABG)
  • Adjust transfusion speed and, if necessary, reduce bicarbonate levels.

Metabolic Acidosis

Inadequate tissue perfusion leads to lactic acid accumulation.

Lowered blood pH (acidosis) leads to confusion, fatigue, rapid breathing, and worsened cardiovascular function.
  • Correct underlying cause (e.g., improve perfusion).
  • Administer sodium bicarbonate in severe cases of acidosis.

Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)

Antibodies in transfused blood activate the recipient's immune response, causing inflammation and fluid buildup in the lungs.

Non-cardiogenic pulmonary oedema, presenting as acute respiratory distress with hypoxia within 6 hours of transfusion.
  • Immediate cessation of transfusion.
  • Oxygen therapy and mechanical ventilation if necessary.

Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload (TACO)

The volume of transfused blood exceeds the patient’s capacity to manage, leading to fluid overload.

Pulmonary oedema, shortness of breath, hypertension, and signs of heart failure.
  • Administer diuretics (e.g., furosemide).
  • Slow the rate of transfusion.

Iron Overload

Repeated transfusions lead to excessive accumulation of iron.

Iron deposits in organs (e.g., liver, heart, pancreas), lead to organ damage and failure over time.

Administer iron chelators (e.g., deferoxamine, deferasirox).

Hemolytic Reactions

ABO or Rh incompatibility.

Rapid destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis), causes fever, chills, hemoglobinuria, and potentially acute renal failure or shock.
  • Immediate cessation of transfusion.
  • Supportive care with IV fluids.

Allergic Reactions

Reaction to proteins in transfused blood products.

Symptoms range from mild itching, rash, or hives to severe anaphylaxis (airway constriction, low blood pressure, shock).
  • Administer antihistamines for mild reactions.
  • Corticosteroids and epinephrine for severe reactions like anaphylaxis.

Bacterial Contamination

Blood products are contaminated during collection or storage.

Sepsis is characterized by fever, chills, low blood pressure, and possibly septic shock.
  • Immediate cessation of transfusion.
  • Administer broad-spectrum antibiotics.

questions.text: What kind of wound is an open cardiac massage?
questions.explanation:
Classification

Description

Class I

Clean

An uninfected operative wound with no inflammation and no entry into the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or uninfected urinary tracts. Wounds are primarily closed, and drainage is closed if needed.

Class II Clean-Contaminated

An operative wound where the respiratory, alimentary, genital, or urinary tracts are entered under controlled conditions without unusual contamination. Includes operations like biliary tract, appendix, vagina, and oropharynx.

Class III

Contaminated

Open, fresh accidental wounds or operations with major breaks in sterile technique

(open cardiac massage) or gross spillage from the gastrointestinal tract, with acute non-purulent inflammation.

Class IV

Dirty-Infected

Old traumatic wounds with retained devitalized tissue, clinical infection, or perforated viscera. The organisms causing postoperative infection were already present in the operative field before the operation.

questions.text: A patient presented with complaints of pain in the flank region with hematuria. On investigation, an X-ray shows multiple calcifications (stones) in both kidneys. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Renal calculi

Medical management

Surgical Management
  • Analgesics like diclofenac, ketorolac, tramadol
  • Fluid therapy: IVF (intravenous fluids) are administered to prevent dehydration
  • Alpha 1 blocker: Tamsulosin (relaxes ureter and expels the stone).
  • Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL): Indicated if the size of the calculi <2 cm. (Contraindicated in pregnancy and bleeding diathesis).
  • PCNL (Percutaneous nephrolithotomy): If the size is >2 cm.
  • Uretrorenoscopy
  • Retrograde intrarenal surgery
  • Pyelolithotomy and nephrolithotomy (rarely used).

questions.text: All of the following tests are done for screening in patients with Turner’s syndrome, except?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - ANA

Condition

Evaluation

Cardiac Abnormalities

EKG (for prolonged QT interval), Blood pressure (upper and lower extremities), Echocardiogram (Option C) or Cardiac MRI for anomalies.

Cognitive Function/Learning Disabilities

Special education assessments and evaluations at school.

Hearing Loss

Serial audiology evaluations (Option B) every 3 years in children, and every 5 years in adults.

Renal Abnormalities

Renal ultrasound at diagnosis.

Ovarian Failure

Serum FSH and AMH at 10-11 years.

Osteoporosis/Bone Health

Screening for low bone mineral density and fractures. Annual screening for scoliosis during growth hormone therapy.

Celiac Disease

Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A antibodies at 2 years, and every 2 years thereafter.

Autoimmune Thyroiditis

TSH and free or total T4 measurements annually starting at 4 years.

Liver Disease

ALT, AST, GGT, and alkaline phosphatase annually after 10 years.

Metabolic Syndrome

Hemoglobin A1c annually, starting at 10 years.

Lipid panel annually if cardiovascular risk factors are present.

Vitamin D Deficiency

Serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D at 9-11 years, and every 2-3 years thereafter.

Gonadoblastoma

Screening for Y chromosome if marker chromosome elements are present or virilization develops.

Screening Laboratory Tests

Fasting blood glucose (Option D), glycated haemoglobin, serum creatinine, and urinalysis at 10 years and above to screen for diabetes mellitus and kidney disease.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drug is recently approved to be used in patients with heart failure with low ejection fraction and reduced urine output?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Empagliflozin

Drug Class

Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) Inhibitors

Examples
  • Canagliflozin
  • Dapagliflozin
  • Empagliflozin (Option B)

Mechanism of Action

Blocks reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubule, promoting the excretion of sodium and glucose in urine

Indications
  • Reduce progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD)
  • Diuretic effect, leading to sodium loss
  • Reduces systolic blood pressure (SBP) by 3-6 mmHg
  • Cardiorenal advantage
  • CHF to decrease mortality with or without DM

Side Effects
  • Increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs)
  • Glucosuria (leading to UTIs and vulvovaginal candidiasis)
  • Dehydration (orthostatic hypotension)
  • Weight loss

Contraindications
  • Not recommended if estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) < 45 ml/min
  • Use with caution in renal insufficiency (decreased efficacy with decreased GFR)

questions.text: A young patient developed hyperpigmentation of distal fingers after being hospitalized post-adrenalectomy. What could be the possible cause?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Nelson syndrome

Definition

Nelson's syndrome is a condition that typically occurs after bilateral adrenalectomy for the treatment of Cushing's disease (pituitary-dependent Cushing’s syndrome). The removal of the adrenal glands leads to a lack of negative feedback on the pituitary, resulting in increased secretion of ACTH. Over time, the pituitary gland may develop a pituitary adenoma (or enlargement of an existing adenoma), which secretes ACTH in excess.

Prevention

Prophylactic radiation therapy may be indicated to prevent the development of Nelson’s syndrome after adrenalectomy

Clinical features

  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Bitemporal hemianopia
  • Progressive visual loss in cases of large tumours
  • Headache
  • Weakness and fatigue
  • Inhibition of the release of other pituitary hormones

Evaluation

  • Fasting Plasma ACTH Levels:
    • Very high levels.
    • Diagnosis confirmed by an ACTH increase >30% of the initial result on three consecutive samples after bilateral adrenalectomy.
  • Decreased levels of anterior pituitary hormones.
  • Brain MRI shows pituitary tumours or enlargement of existing tumours.
  • Screening:
    • Regular screening with fasting plasma ACTH levels and brain MRI in patients after bilateral adrenalectomy.

Management

  • Surgical Removal of the Tumor
  • Radiotherapy / Radiosurgery
  • Medical Treatment
  • Hormonal Replacement Therapy

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are not used for thyrotoxic crisis management?
questions.explanation:
Thyroid Storm

About
  • A thyroid storm, or thyrotoxic crisis, is an acute, life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism.
  • It presents with multisystem involvement and has a mortality rate of 8 to 25% despite advancements in treatment.

Etiology
  • Most commonly associated with Graves' disease but can also occur in toxic multinodular goitre and toxic thyroid adenoma.
  • Precipitating Factors:
    • Abrupt discontinuation of antithyroid medications.
    • Thyroid surgery.
    • Non-thyroid surgery.
    • Acute illnesses (e.g., infections, diabetic ketoacidosis, myocardial infarction, stroke) act as stressors that can trigger excess thyroid hormone release.
    • Parturition (childbirth).
    • Recent use of iodinated contrast medium.
    • Trauma or Burns or traumatic brain injury.
    • Medication side effects (e.g., amiodarone, anaesthetics, salicylates).
    • Raised beta-hcg conditions such as complete mole, twin pregnancies

Clinical Features
  • Fever: High temperature (104°F to 106°F) with diaphoresis.
  • Cardiovascular Involvement: Tachycardia (>140 bpm), heart failure, arrhythmias, hypotension, and risk of cardiac arrest.
  • CNS Manifestations: Agitation, delirium, anxiety, psychosis, or coma.
  • Gastrointestinal Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, intestinal obstruction, and acute hepatic failure.
  • Physical Exam Findings: Tachycardia, goitre, hand tremors, moist and warm skin, hyperreflexia, systolic hypertension, and jaundice.

Management
  • Initial Supportive Measures: IV fluids, oxygen, cooling blankets, and acetaminophen (Option A).
  • Beta-blocker Therapy: Start with propranolol (Option D) immediately (40-80 mg every 4-6 hours) to control adrenergic tone.
  • Thionamide Therapy: Administer propylthiouracil (500-1000 mg loading, then 250 mg every 4 hours) or methimazole (20 mg every 4-6 hours). This reduces thyroid hormone synthesis.
  • Iodine Solution (Option C): Give SSKI (5 drops every 6 hours) after thionamide to reduce the release of thyroid hormone
  • Glucocorticoids: Hydrocortisone (100 mg IV every 8 hours) or dexamethasone (2 mg every 6 hours).
  • Therapy to block peripheral conversion of T4 to T3: Iodinated radiocontrast agent, glucocorticoid, PTU, propranolol
  • Cholestyramine (Bile acid sequestrant): 4 grams orally 4 times daily for severe cases to reduce enterohepatic recycling of thyroid hormone.
  • Monitoring: Admit to ICU with close cardiac monitoring and ventilatory support if needed.
  • Alternative Medications: Esmolol as a short-acting beta-blocker; diltiazem if beta-blockers are contraindicated.
  • Surgery: Thyroidectomy for patients with contraindications to thionamides after pre-treatment.
  • Definitive Treatment: Recommend radioiodine therapy or surgery for hyperthyroidism once stabilized.

In the outpatient department, a female patient presents with arthritis that symmetrically affects multiple joints, including the wrists, hands, and feet. The patient reports morning stiffness lasting for more than 1 hour, and examination reveals swollen and tender joints.
questions.explanation:
Disease

Joint involved & characteristics

Joint spared

Osteoarthritis (Option C)
  • Proximal and Distal interphalangeal joints (PIP and DIP), 1st Carpometacarpal joint, Hip and knee
  • Asymmetrical involvement
  • Wrist and Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option A)
  • Metacarpophalangeal joint (MCP) - most commonly involved
  • Symmetrical involvement seen
  • Morning stiffness present
  • Distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) and 1st carpometacarpal (CMP) joint

Psoriatic arthritis (Option B)
  • Proximal and Distal interphalangeal joints (PIP and DIP)
  • Pencil-in-cup, telescoping of digits, arthritis mutilans
  • Skin and nail involvement +
  • Ray pattern distribution of joints seen

Description
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a common chronic inflammatory joint disease characterized by symmetrical polyarthritis, tenosynovitis, morning stiffness, elevated ESR, and presence of autoantibodies (RF and ACPA). It’s a systemic condition affecting various tissues.

Causes
  • Genetic susceptibility (e.g., HLA-DR4 association).
  • Immunological reaction involving synovial tissue.
  • Inflammatory response in joints and tendon sheaths.
  • Rheumatoid factors (RF) and anti-citrullinated peptides (ACPA/ anti-CCP antibodies).
  • Articular cartilage destruction.

Stages
  • Stage 1: Pre-clinical- Immune changes begin, detectable ESR, CRP, and RF.
  • Stage 2: Synovitis- Inflammation, vascular congestion, and synoviocyte proliferation.
  • Stage 3: Destruction- Joint and tendon damage, cartilage erosion, and bone resorption.
  • Stage 4: Deformity- Joint instability, capsular stretching, and tendon rupture leading to deformity.

Clinical Features
  • Early: Pain, swelling, stiffness in small joints (e.g., fingers, wrists), especially after inactivity.
  • Later: Joint deformity (e.g., ulnar deviation, clawed toes), restricted movements, and constant ache.
  • Extra-articular features include subcutaneous nodules, muscle wasting, scleritis, and vasculitis.

Named deformities in RA
  • Boutonnière deformity: Also known as buttonhole deformity, this occurs when the middle joint of a finger bends downward, while the top joint bends away from the palm.
  • Swan-neck deformity: This occurs when the base and top joint of a finger bend downward, while the middle joint is straight.
  • Ulnar deviation: Also known as ulnar drift, this occurs when fingers bend toward the outer side of the forearm.
  • Hitchhiker's thumb: Also known as Z-shaped deformity, this occurs when the thumb flexes at the joint where it meets the palm, then bends backward at the joint below the thumbnail.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient is undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During the surgery, a sudden decrease in etCO2 to 8 mm Hg was observed. The patient's SpO2 was 90% and peak airway pressure was 18 mm Hg. His blood pressure also dropped to 80/50 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Air Embolism

Occurs when air enters accidentally into the vascular system.Commonly iatrogenic via interventional procedures, but also from trauma, diving, childbirth, and other circumstances.

Causes

  • Through venous access like IV cannula.
  • Artificial Pneumothorax.
  • Surgeries of neck and axilla.
  • Traumatic opening of major veins sucking air inside.
  • Fallopian tube insufflation.
  • Laparoscopic surgeries.
  • Illegal abortions.

Symptoms
  • Respiratory Distress,
  • Hemoptysis,
  • Convulsions,
  • Unconsciousness,
  • Visual and hearing disturbances,
  • Fatigue and numbness,
  • Paralysis,
  • Hemodynamic instability,
  • Coma.

Diagnosis

  • Patient history especially relation to recent procedures.
  • Auscultation: Millwheel murmur heard over the precordium is diagnostic.
  • ECG: ST depression and right heart strain due to pulmonary artery obstruction.
  • Capnometry: Decreased end-tidal CO2 levels in intubated patients.
  • Imaging: Chest X-ray, Doppler ultrasonography, transesophageal echocardiography (TEE).

Treatment

  • Positioning:
    • Trendelenburg position: Keeps air bubbles away from coronary arteries.
    • Left lateral decubitus position: Helps trap air in the non-dependent segment of the right ventricle, preventing it from entering the pulmonary artery.
  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: Useful in both venous and arterial air embolism as it reduces ischemia, bubble size; in arterial embolism it removes nitrogen from bubbles to improve perfusion and oxygenation.
  • Aspiration: Air should be aspirated from the right ventricle with a needle.
  • Open Thoracotomy: Life-saving procedure required to aspirate excess air causing the block.

questions.text: Liver produces ketones but cannot use it due to the deficiency of which of the following?

Ketone Bodies

Tissues that use Ketone Bodies
  • Almost all tissues except:
    • Liver
    • Red blood cells (RBCs)
  • Tissues that prefer ketone bodies:
    • Heart muscle
    • Renal cortex
    • Placenta
  • Tissues that use ketone bodies only in the absence of glucose:
    • Skeletal muscle
    • Brain
  • Additional Tissues Using Ketone Bodies
    • Intestinal mucosal cells
    • Adipocytes

Enzyme Involved
  • Thiophorase: Converts acetoacetate to acetoacetyl CoA

Fatty Acids as Primary Energy Source During Starvation
  • Skeletal muscles
  • Heart
  • Liver

Energy Production Pathway
  • Acetoacetyl CoA enters the beta-oxidation pathway to produce energy

Which of the following statements given below is incorrect regarding CPR in adults?

options.label: A
options.text: Depth of chest compression up to 5-6 cm

questions.explanation:
Compressions (C)

Position: Place the patient in a supine position on a firm surface.

Site: Lower ⅓ rd of sternum

Rate: 100 to 120 compressions per minute. (Option D ruled out)

Depth: Compress 2 to 2.4 inches (5-6 cm); avoid exceeding 2.4 inches. (Option A ruled out)

Compression-to-Ventilation Ratio: 30 compressions to 2 breaths (30:2). (Option C)

Chest Recoil: Allow full recoil between compressions to optimize blood flow. (Option B ruled out)

Interruptions: Minimize interruptions in compressions (<10 seconds).

Chest Compression Fraction (CCF): The proportion of time spent performing chest compressions during CPR: Maintain a CCF ≥ 60%.

For pregnant women: perform manual lateral uterine displacement (LUD) to relieve pressure on large abdominal vessels.

Airway (A)

Head Tilt-Chin Lift: Used to open the airway in patients without suspected neck trauma.

Jaw Thrust: Preferred method, if neck trauma is suspected.

The most common cause of airway obstruction in unconscious patients is the tongue falling back.

Breathing (B)

Rescue Breaths: Give 2 breaths after every 30 compressions.

Method: Mouth-to-mouth or with a bag-mask device, ensuring chest rise with each breath.

Breath Duration: Each breath should last about 1 second.

questions.text: The marked structure relays efferents to which nucleus of the thalamus? [
Which is a rare but very serious side effect of clozapine that requires regular monitoring?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Agranulocytosis

Serious Adverse Effects of Clozapine

Agranulocytosis
  • Rare but life-threatening decrease in white blood cells, requiring weekly monitoring.
  • Discontinue if total leukocyte count < 3000/mm³ or absolute neutrophil count < 2000/mm³.
  • Avoid combining with carbamazepine.
  • Monitoring of agranulocytosis: 1st 6 weeks - weekly; Next 6 months- Fortnightly; After 1 year- Monthly

Seizures
  • Dose-dependent seizure risk. Higher than other atypical antipsychotics.

Cardiac Effects
  • Risk of tachycardia, myocarditis (fatal, within first 6 wks) and dilated cardiomyopathy.

Non-serious Adverse effects of Clozapine

Hypersalivation

  • Known as "wet pillow syndrome" due to muscarinic receptor stimulation.

Metabolic Complications
  • Significant risk of weight gain, hyperglycemia, and dyslipidemia.
  • Associated with increased appetite due to 5-HT2C receptor blockade.

Cataracts
  • Higher risk than other atypical antipsychotics.

Effects on Pregnancy and Breastfeeding
  • Can cause decreased arousal and hypotonia in neonates.
  • C/I during breastfeeding due to the risk of neutropenia, sedation, and seizures in infants.

questions.text: Sodium valproate has an inhibitory action at which of the following sites?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - B

Sodium Valproate

Mechanism of Action
  • Sodium Channel Inactivation: Prolongs Na+ channel inactivation in a frequency-dependent manner, similar to phenytoin.
  • Calcium Channel Modulation: Weakly attenuates the T-type calcium currents, akin to ethosuximide.
  • GABA Enhancement: Increases GABA levels by:
    • Inhibiting GABA transaminase, leading to reduced degradation.
    • Possibly enhancing GABA synthesis from glutamic acid.
  • Glutamate Receptor Blockade: Blocks excitatory NMDA glutamate receptors, reducing excitatory neurotransmission.

Uses

  • Seizure Disorders: It is the DOC for atypical absence seizures, myoclonic seizures, and generalised tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS).
  • Mood Disorders: Valproate is effective in the treatment of mania and bipolar disorder.
  • Panic Attacks: It can be used off-label for the treatment of panic attacks.
  • Migraine Prophylaxis: Valproate is considered a second-line treatment for preventing migraines.
  • Mixed Seizure Syndromes: It is used in conditions such as Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.
  • Severe Myoclonic Epilepsy of Infancy: Valproate is also used in Dravet syndrome.

Adverse Effects
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, and indigestion.
  • Neurological: Tremor, sedation, dizziness, and ataxia.
  • Hepatic: Hepatotoxicity (mainly in children <2 years of age).
  • Hematologic: Thrombocytopenia and other blood dyscrasias.
  • Metabolic: Weight gain, hyperammonemia, and pancreatitis.
  • Teratogenicity: Risk of congenital malformations, such as neural tube defects (spina bifida oculta), if used during pregnancy.
  • Others: Hair loss (alopecia) and polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

Drug interactions

Valproate is a CYP enzyme inhibitor that inhibits CYP2C9, which can lead to increased levels of drugs metabolised by this enzyme, such as phenytoin and warfarin

Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the vector shown below?
questions.explanation:
Scrub typhus

Causative agent

Orientia tsutsugamushi - It differs from Rickettsia both genetically and by its cell wall composition i.e. it lacks lipopolysaccharide layer.

Vector

Chiggers (larvae of trombiculid mite)

Pathophysiology
  • Scrub typhus is so named because it occurs in areas of scrub vegetation i.e. low lying trees and bushes.
  • It is transmitted by the bite of infected trombiculid mites.
  • Among all stages of mite, the larvae (called chiggers) are the only stage that feed on humans. Hence, scrub typhus is also called chiggerosis.
  • Mites can maintain the organisms through transovarial transmission.
  • Orientia tsutsugamushi infects mononuclear cells but still produces fever and rash.

Clinical features

  • The classic presentation of scrub typhus consists of triad of an eschar (at the site of bite), regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash sparing palms and soles.
  • Non-specific manifestations may appear early such as fever, headache, myalgia, cough, and gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Complications such as encephalitis and interstitial pneumonia may occur rarely in the late stage (due to vascular injury).

Investigations

The Weil-Felix test shows OX K+ only.

Treatment

  • Doxycycline is the drug choice.
  • Azithromycin is given alternatively and the drug of choice in children and pregnant women.

PLP acts as a coenzyme for many reactions in amino acid metabolism.

Transamination

Catalyzed by amino transferases (e.g., Alanine transaminase), converting amino acids to keto acids.

Decarboxylation

Required for decarboxylation of amino acids, forming important neurotransmitters and metabolites.

Neurotransmitter Synthesis
  • GABA from glutamate (important for inhibitory neurotransmission).
  • Histamine from histidine (mediator of allergy).
  • Serotonin from 5-hydroxy tryptophan (mood regulation).
  • Taurine from cysteine.

Sulfur Containing Amino Acids

Involved in methionine and cysteine metabolism.

Homocysteine Metabolism

Converts homocysteine to cystathionine; deficiency leads to increased homocysteine, associated with myocardial infarction risk.

Heme Synthesis

Required for ALA synthase, the rate-limiting enzyme in heme biosynthesis.

Niacin Production

Required for the conversion of tryptophan to niacin (via kynurenine).

Glycogenolysis

PLP is a coenzyme for phosphorylase, which converts glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate.

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department with complaints of facial pain, swelling, and nasal discharge. The patient was recently hospitalized for a COVID-19 infection and treated with a prolonged course of steroids. Examination of the nasal discharge under the microscope shows the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Mucormycosis

It is an invasive disease caused by zygomycetes (phycomycetes) - Rhizopus, Mucor and Absidia. Rhizopus Arrhizus is the most common pathogen

Rhizopus:

Absidia:

Mucor (Lactophenol cotton blue stained):

 

 

Pathogenesis

Begins in the respiratory tract or nasal cavity, where spores germinate and form mycelia → invade adjacent tissues, leading to local destruction.

Fungi invade blood vessels, causing thrombosis and infarction in affected areas, which contributes to its high mortality rate (Angio-invasiveness)

Common Sites

  • Rhinocerebral Form: Involves the nose, nasal sinuses, and orbit; frequently seen in diabetic patients.
  • Pulmonary Infections: When the lungs are the primary site, the fungi can invade lung arteries, leading to serious complications.
  • Others: Cutaneous mucormycosis, GI mucormycosis, Disseminated mucormycosis

Clinical Features
  • Rhinocerebral Zygomycosis:
    • Facial swelling, nasal discharge (often black), fever, and mucosal necrosis.
    • Rapid progression can lead to severe complications, including visual loss and neurological symptoms.
  • Pulmonary Zygomycosis:
    • Symptoms may include cough, fever, and hemoptysis

Diagnosis

Histological Examination:

Diagnosis is confirmed by identifying broad, non-septate (or sparsely septate) hyphae.

Culture:

  • After incubation for 3-4 days on Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, the colonies are grey-white with a thick cottony, fluffy surface.
  • Under the microscope, nonseptate, broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores are seen.)

a. Sabouraud's dextrose agar (SDA) medium showing Rhizopus growth

b. Microscopy of LPCB stained preparation demonstrating morphology of Rhizopus spp. (non-septate hyphae, sporangiophore, sporangium and spores)

Treatment:
  • Intravenous amphotericin B combined, where appropriate, with surgical drainage is the recommended treatment.
  • Medical control of diabetes is required.

Features

Aspergillus

Mucor

Branching

<45°

>90° or 90°

Hyphae

Septate

Aseptate

Shape

Thin

Broad ribbon-like

questions.explanation:
Properties of Enzyme

Nature of Enzymes

Enzymes are proteins, heat-sensitive, water-soluble

Efficiency

Enzymes can accelerate reactions by factors 10^6 to 10^9 or more.

Specificity

Enzymes act on specific substrates and can distinguish stereoisomers.

Cofactors/Coenzymes

Some enzymes need non-protein molecules (cofactors or coenzymes) to be active.

Substrate Binding

Enzymes bind substrates at multiple points, creating chiral products from non-chiral substrates.

Transition State

Enzymes stabilize the transition state, lowering activation energy.

Reversibility

Enzymes can catalyze both forward and reverse reactions.

Regulation

Activity is regulated by pH, temperature, inhibitors, and activators.

Active site

  • The region where the substrate binds and undergoes a chemical reaction
  • It is most complimentary to enzyme-substrate

    • Fixed virus:

questions.explanation:
CONGENITAL RUBELLA SYNDROME

Definition
  • Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) occurs in infants who have contracted rubella from their mothers while in utero.
  • The most likely time for this to occur is between 8-10 weeks of gestation.
  • After birth, these babies can transmit the virus to others for a period of 12–18 months.

Dermatological presentation
  • Blueberry Muffin Rash (Option D ruled out)
  • Forchheimer Spots- small, red or purple spots that can appear on the soft palate

Ophthalmic Defects
  • Cataracts
  • Microphthalmia
  • Glaucoma
  • Salt and pepper retinopathy
  • Chorioretinitis

Auditory Defects
  • Sensorineural deafness

Cardiac Defects
  • Peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis
  • Patent ductus arteriosus
  • Ventricular septal defects

Craniofacial Defects
  • Microcephaly

Other Infant Presentations
  • Meningoencephalitis
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Interstitial pneumonitis
  • Radiolucency in the long bones

 

Diagnosis

 
  • Hemagglutination inhibition test (HAI) is the commonly preferred test.
  • Presence of IgM antibodies shortly after birth.
  • Presence of IgG antibodies lasting >6 months.
  • IgM positive implies in-utero infection because IgM antibodies cannot pass from mother to child through the placenta.

questions.explanation:
Bacterial Meningitis in Adults and Prevention

Causes

Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitides are the primary causes. Listeria monocytogenes is a significant risk in adults over 50, especially in those with diabetes, alcoholism, or weakened immune systems.

Pathophysiological Process

Treatment
  • Immediate Management: Start with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics to cover pathogens. Treatment is then changed based on the identified organism and its susceptibility.
  • Adjunctive Therapy: Dexamethasone may be given to reduce inflammation and prevent complications, particularly if administered early.
  • Supportive Care: Manage complications like raised intracranial pressure and seizures.

Prevention

 
  • Vaccines for H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis, and S. pneumoniae. No vaccine currently exists for group B meningococcal infections.
  • Chemoprophylaxis: Close contacts of individuals with meningococcal meningitis should receive prophylactic antibiotics like rifampicin, ciprofloxacin, azithromycin or ceftriaxone to reduce the risk of secondary infections.
    • Rifampicin - 600 mg 12 hourly for 2 days
    • Ciprofloxacin - 500 mg single dose
    • Azithromycin 500 mg single dose
    • Ceftriaxone - 250 mg Intramuscular single dose

questions.correct_answer: B. Optimum sample for PCR is blood/urine/saliva sample within 2-3 weeks of birth
questions.explanation:
Causative Agent

Cytomegalovirus (CMV), a member of the herpesvirus family

Transmission

Vertical transmission from mother to fetus during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding.

Incidence

CMV is the most common congenital viral infection, affecting approximately 0.5-2% of all live births.

Incubation Period

3–12 weeks

Risk Period

Highest fetal risk occurs when the mother contracts CMV during pregnancy, particularly in the first trimester

Classical Triad

1. Sensorineural deafness

2. Microcephaly

3. Chorioretinitis

Clinical Features in Neonates

Asymptomatic in 80-90% of cases

 

Symptomatic in 10-20% of cases, with signs such as:

  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Jaundice
  • Petechial rash,
  • Microcephaly
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Seizures
  • Intracranial periventricular calcifications.

Long-Term Sequelae
  • Hearing loss (most common)
  • Developmental delay
  • Visual impairment (e.g., chorioretinitis)
  • Cerebral palsy
  • Seizure disorders

Diagnosis
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by detecting CMV DNA using PCR in urine, saliva, or blood collected within the first 2-3 weeks of life.
  • Preferred sample: Urine > saliva > blood
  • IgM antibody detection in fetal blood is less reliable.

Management

Ganciclovir or valganciclovir may be used in symptomatic infants with progressive neurologic disease or hearing loss.

Prognosis
  • Asymptomatic infants generally have a normal long-term outcome
  • Symptomatic infants may have developmental and neurological impairments

questions.text: An autopsy was conducted on a male with a history of drowning. No water was found in his lungs, and he was labeled a case of dry drowning. What is the cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Types of atypical drowning

Dry drowning

  • In dry drowning, water does not enter the lungs due to laryngeal spasms induced by small amounts of water entering the larynx.
  • Cause of death: Reflex cardiac arrest due to vasovagal stimulation.

Immersion syndrome (Cold water drowning)
  • It refers to syncope resulting from cardiac arrhythmias on sudden
  • contact with water that is at least 5°C lower than the body temperature.
  • Also called hydrocution or submersion inhibition.

Near drowning (post-immersion syndrome or secondary drowning)
  • Near drowning refers to survival beyond 24 hours after a submersion episode.
  • Death is caused by complications or sequelae like ARDS, pneumonia, sepsis, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, and DIC.

Features

Freshwater drowning

Seawater drowning

Cause of death

Ventricular fibrillation

Cardiac arrest due to fulminant pulmonary edema.

Changes in blood

Hemodilution, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypochloremia

Hemoconcentration, hypernatremia, hypovolemia, hypochloremia.

Lungs

Pinkish in colour, emphysematous, crepitus is heard

Purplish or bluish colour, soft in consistency, no crepitus is heard.

Copious fluid and froth are seen.

Fatal period

4-5 minutes

8-12 minutes

questions.text: Choose the correct statements for cystic fibrosis: i. Increased Cl- in sweat. ii. Decreased Cl- in sweat. iii. Increased Cl- in pancreatic juice. iv. Decreased Cl- in pancreatic juice.
questions.explanation:
Genetic Basis
  • Gene: CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator)
  • Location: Chromosome 7q31.2
  • Common Mutation: ΔF508
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive

Pathophysiology

 

  • CFTR Dysfunction: Defective chloride transport, increased sodium absorption, dehydrated mucus
  • Metabolic: (Hypokalemia) Due to excessive loss of potassium through sweat and impaired renal potassium handling
  • Respiratory: Airway obstruction, bacterial colonization, bronchiectasis, respiratory failure
  • Gastrointestinal: Pancreatic duct obstruction, malabsorption, Distal Intestinal Obstruction Syndrome
  • Sweat Glands: Salty sweat
  • Reproductive:
    Infertility in males: Congenital absence of the vas deferens in males leading to azoospermia and infertility.
    Infertility in females: Defective CFTR in the cervix leads to the production of thick, dehydrated cervical mucus that blocks the cervical os, impairing sperm entry and reducing fertility.

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory: Chronic productive cough, recurrent infections, bronchiectasis
  • Gastrointestinal: Steatorrhea, malabsorption, meconium ileus, failure to thrive
  • Genitourinary: Infertility (males), delayed puberty
  • Other: Digital clubbing, salt-loss syndromes (Contraction alkalosis)

Diagnosis

Diagnostic Criteria

Requirement 1: Any ONE of the following

 

  • Clinical Features: Presence of typical features
  • Family History: A sibling with diagnosed cystic fibrosis
  • Newborn Screening: Positive result indicating risk for CF
  • IRT Screening: Elevated Immunoreactive Trypsinogen (IRT) for pancreatic insufficiency

Requirement 2: At least ONE of the following

Laboratory Evidence:

 

  • Sweat Chloride Test: Two elevated sweat chloride concentrations on separate days ≥60 mMol/L (Pilocarpine iontophoresis method)
  • CFTR Mutations: Identification of two CFTR mutations
  • Nasal Potential Difference: Abnormal measurement

Microbes
  • <18 years: Staphylococcus aureus
  • >18 years: Pseudomonas aeruginosa

 

  • Burkholderia cepacia: High mortality, low incidence

Management Strategies
  • Airway Clearance: Chest physiotherapy, percussion, postural drainage
  • Infection Control: Antibiotics, CFTR modulators
  • Nutritional Support: High-calorie diet, PERT, vitamin supplementation (A, D, E, K)
  • Other: Insulin for CFRD, bone health management

Advanced Therapies
  • CFTR Modulators: Ivacaftor, lumacaftor, Trikafta
  • Trikafta: Elexacaftor-Tezacaftor-Ivacaftor (≥2 years old), improves lung function, reduces sweat chloride

questions.text: One-day-old term neonate presented with respiratory distress, tachypnea, SpO2-80%, and scaphoid abdomen. Which of the following cannot be used in resuscitation?
questions.explanation:
Etiology

Failure of closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal during fetal development (normally by 8-10 weeks gestation).

Prevalence of Sides

Left-sided hernias are more common (80%).

Common Hernia Sites

1. Foramen of Morgagni: Hernia in the anteromedial part of the diaphragm (defect between sternal and costal attachments), often involving the transverse colon.

2. Foramen of Bochdalek: Hernia through the dome of the diaphragm posterolaterally.

 

Pathophysiology

Pulmonary hypoplasia (bilateral), leading to smaller bronchi, reduced bronchial branching, and less alveolar surface area. May cause pulmonary hypertension due to thickened arteriolar smooth muscle.

Clinical Features
  • Respiratory distress at birth
  • Grunting respiration
  • Chest retractions
  • Dyspnea
  • Cyanosis
  • Scaphoid abdomen
  • Decreased breath sounds with bowel sounds heard over the chest
  • Shifting of heart sounds to the right (for left-sided CDH).

Associated Complications

Pulmonary hypoplasia, pulmonary hypertension, increased systemic vasoactive factors.

Diagnosis

Clinical evaluation (respiratory distress, scaphoid abdomen, etc.), imaging (X-ray, ultrasound, or CT scan).

Management

Immediate resuscitation and stabilization, surgical repair of the diaphragm defect.

Contraindication

Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated due to risk of insufflation of abdominal contents into the chest cavity. Intubation is preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding sample collection in a case of alcohol intoxication?

options.label: B
options.text: Sample area cleaned with soap and water

options.label: C
options.text: Sample should be preserved without preservative

options.label: D
options.text: Only one urine sample is required

questions.correct_answer: B. Sample area cleaned with soap and water
questions.explanation:
Alcohol sample collection

Cleaning the Skin
  • Avoid using spirit or alcohol on skin or syringe.
  • Use 1:1000 mercuric chloride solution or soap and water.

Preservation of Blood
  • Add 100 mg sodium fluoride and 30 mg potassium oxalate to 10 mL blood.
  • Shake thoroughly to prevent alcohol loss due to glycolysis and bacterial activity.

Alternate Preservatives
  • Use 50 mg phenyl mercuric nitrate or sodium azide for 10 mL blood or urine.

Storage Containers
  • Use screw-capped glass bottles to minimize alcohol evaporation.
  • Avoid rubber stoppers to prevent contamination from oxidizable substances.
  • Label containers with name, date, and time of collection.

Storage Guidelines
  • Refrigerate if not sent to the lab immediately; avoid freezing (prevents cell lysis).
  • Samples maintain alcohol concentration for weeks at room temperature.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes lithium?

options.label: A
options.text: It can cause fine postural tremors at a therapeutic dosage

options.label: B
options.text: It is not absorbed from the gut

questions.correct_answer: A. It can cause fine postural tremors at a therapeutic dosage
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - It can cause fine postural tremors at a therapeutic dosage

Lithium

Mechanism of action

  • Increase the level of amine (if the mood is low) by inhibiting the Glycogen synthase kinase-3 enzyme
  • Decrease the level of amine (if the mood is high)
    • Inhibits inositol monophosphatase enzyme
    • Inhibits the release of amines
    • Stabilises neuronal membrane

Uses

  • Bipolar disorder
  • Hypnic headache (occurs in sleep)
  • Anti-suicidal action (another drug is clozapine)
  • Resistant cases of depression

Adverse effects
  • Alopecia and acne
  • Weight gain
  • Seizures and sinus node dysfunction (leading to AV block)
  • Hypothyroidism (hyperthyroidism in rare cases)
  • High doses can cause coarse tremors, ataxia, tinnitus, diarrhea, and seizures.
  • Ebstein’s anomaly: A cardiovascular defect called tricuspid atresia, which has a teratogenic effect when administered to pregnant women.
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI)
  • Fine tremors (most common adverse effect)
  • ECG changes: T-wave flattening
  • Leukocytosis
  • Loose stools (diarrhea)

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presents with scaly lesions over the body, as shown in the Image below. No other associated symptoms are present. What is the likely diagnosis?
Due to the requirement of regular blood monitoring, what rare side effects must be considered for a patient undergoing treatment with clozapine who is diagnosed with schizophrenia?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer A - Agranulocytosis

Class

Atypical antipsychotic (1st atypical antipsychotic discovered)

Mechanism of action

Primarily works as a dopamine D2 receptor antagonist, but it also has significant effects on serotonin receptors (5-HT2A and 5-HT2C), which helps reduce symptoms in treatment-resistant cases.

Uses

  • DOC for TRS (Treatment-resistant schizophrenia): Used only when a patient doesn't respond to at least 2 antipsychotics.
  • Only antipsychotics with anti-suicidal properties (shown ↓ suicidal ideas in Schizophrenia patients).

Side effects

Severe risks (Pneumonic: SAM):

  • S - Seizures (Option C ruled out)
    • Dose dependant
    • > 600 mg has more seizures
  • A - Agranulocytosis (Option A)
    • Idiosyncratic
    • ↓ WBC (Neutrophils)
    • The main reason for deaths and withdrawal from the market
    • Weekly monitoring of WBC and Neutrophil count for 1st 6 months is important
  • M - Myocarditis (Option B ruled out)
    • Idiosyncratic
    • Chest pain
    • Dyspnea
    • Abnormal ECG

 

Common side effects:

  • Sedation (most common)
  • Weight gain (maximum weight gain of all antipsychotics)
  • Hypersalivation (sialorrhea)
  • Sedation
  • Tachycardia
  • Nausea
  • Vomiting
  • Constipation
  • Hypotension

Rare side effects include myocarditis.

Contraindications

  • WBC count - < 3500/mm
  • Previous bone marrow disorder
  • H/o of Agranulocytosis during Clozapine treatment
  • Use of another bone marrow suppressant (carbamazepine)

Monitoring

TLC and ANC

  • Once a week for the first 6 months
  • Once in two weeks for the next 6 months
  • Once a month till the patient continues

questions.text: A boy is experiencing low mood, decreased energy and decreased interest in his surroundings. He has not been taking food for the past one week. The thought sample says - ‘I lost my head. I am dead. How can I eat?’. What type of delusion does the patient exhibit?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Nihilistic delusion

Type

Description

Persecutory (Delusion of persecution)

Believing others are trying to harm them

Jealous (Delusion of infidelity or Othello syndrome)

Believing that a lover or partner is unfaithful

Erotomanic  (Delusion of erotomania or De Clerambault’s syndrome)

Believing that another person (often of higher status) is in love with them

Somatic type

Believing he or she has some physical disorder that includes:

  • Delusion of parasitosis (infested with parasites, such as bugs or worms)
  • Delusion of dysmorphophobia (body or appearance is distorted or altered in a negative way)
  • Delusion of halitosis (bad breath)

Grandiose  (Delusion of grandeur)

Believing one has exceptional abilities, wealth, or fame

Delusion of Guilt

Believing that they are an evil person and have ruined their family

Nihilistic delusion (Option B)

Deny the existence of their body, mind, loved ones, or the world, claiming they have no intelligence, that parts of their body are absent, or even believing they are dead or that the world has ended

Delusion of Poverty

Believing they are impoverished and that destitution threatens them and their family.

Mixed and unspecified type (Delusion of misidentification)

(Option A ruled out)

Delusions that are a combination of types or not described by one of the categories:

  • Capgras syndrome
  • Fregoli syndrome
  • Syndrome of metamorphosis
  • Syndrome of subjective doubles

questions.text: A 9-month-old child is brought to the PHC with a fever and cough. She is feeding well and has normal urine output. On examination, a respiratory rate of 48 breaths/min is found, and no chest indrawing is seen. What is the next step of management?

options.label: A
options.text: Explain danger signs and send home

options.label: B
options.text: No pneumonia—Give amoxyclav + paracetamol and send home

options.label: D
options.text: Refer as the child has severe pneumonia

questions.correct_answer: A. Explain danger signs and send home
questions.explanation:
Ask

Look

Action
  • Able to drink or breastfeed?
  • Does the child vomit everything?
  • H/O convulsions during this illness?
  • Lethargic or unconscious?
  • Currently convulsing?
  • If any danger signs are present, the child needs URGENT attention.

Classification

Signs

Treatment

Severe Pneumonia or Very Severe Disease
  • Any general danger sign
  • Oxygen saturation < 90%
  • Stridor in calm child
  • Central cyanosis
  • Convulsions
  • AVPU = V, P, or U
  • Start oxygen therapy if saturation < 90%.
  • Administer Benzyl Penicillin (or Ampicillin) & Gentamicin.
  • Ceftriaxone should be used as a second-line treatment in children with severe pneumonia having failed on the first-line treatment.
  • Give diazepam if convulsing.
  • Prevent hypoglycemia.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Urgent referral or admission.

Pneumonia
  • Chest indrawing in calm child
  • Fast breathing
  • No signs of severe pneumonia
  • Administer Amoxicillin Dispersible Tablets.
  • Give Vitamin A.
  • Treat wheeze if present.
  • Follow-up in 5 days.
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

No Pneumonia (Cough or Cold)
  • No signs of pneumonia or very severe disease.
  • Treat wheeze if present with salbutamol for 5 days.
  • Advise on immediate return signs.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indicator of fetal lung maturity?

options.label: D
options.text: Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells

questions.correct_answer: D. Nile blue test showing >50% of blue cells
questions.explanation:
Test

Description

Interpretation

Lecithin-sphingomyelin (L/S) ratio
  • Measures the ratio of lecithin to sphingomyelin in amniotic fluid.
  • Lecithin increases with lung maturity, while sphingomyelin remains stable.

A ratio >2 indicates fetal lung maturity. (Option A ruled out)

Shake Test (Bubble Test, Clement's Test)
  • Amniotic fluid is mixed with 95% ethanol and shaken.
  • Observed for bubbles at the meniscus after 15 minutes.

A complete ring of bubbles suggests fetal lung maturity. (Option B ruled out)

Phosphatidylglycerol (PG)
  • Marker of lung maturity, typically appears in amniotic fluid after 35 weeks of gestation.

Presence of PG indicates fetal lung maturity. (Option C ruled out)

Nile Blue Test
  • Uses 0.1% Nile blue sulfate to stain desquamated fetal cells in amniotic fluid.
  • Observes for color changes in stained cells.
  • >50% orange-stained cells indicate lung maturity.
  • Blue-stained cells do not indicate maturity.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presents with eczematous Itching lesions. Blopsy revealed a subepidermal cleft with Direct Immunofluorescence showIng Linear C3 & IgG deposition along the basement membrane zone. What is the likely diagnosis?
The tactile hallucinations seen in cases of chronic cocaine intoxication are:
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer D - Formication

Cocaine

Origin

Leaves of Erythroxylum coca

 

Local names

Coke, snow, Cadillac, White lady

Physical properties

Colourless, odourless, crystalline, bitter taste

Mechanism of action

  • It is a potent central nervous system (CNS) stimulant that produces initial euphoria and increased energy, followed by depression as its effects wear off.
  • It enhances alertness and activity while stimulating the autonomic nervous system, leading to increased heart rate and elevated blood pressure.

Route of administration

Snorting, Smoking, IV injection.

Signs of abuse

  • Septal perforation
  • Crack hands (multiple blackened, hyperkeratotic lesions on the fingers and palms).
  • Black staining of tongue and teeth

Effects

Stages

1. Stage of excitement

  • Feeling of well-being
  • Loss of depression and fatigue
  • Excited and restless
  • Tingling sensation in hands and feet
  • Increased heart rate
  • Increase in temperature
  • Rapid and deep respiration

2. Stage of depression

  • Profuse perspiration
  • Convulsion
  • Reduced respiratory rate

Complications

  • Cardiac arrhythmia
  • Cardiac failure
  • Cardiovascular collapse
  • Cerebrovascular accident
  • Aortic dissection
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Skin necrosis
  • Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Formication (Cocaine Bugs)

Management of fatal dose

  • Maintain airway, breathing and circulation.
  • If ingested: Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate
  • If snorted: Wash the nasal mucous membrane with water
  • If injected: Ligature over the injection site.
  • Amyl nitrite via inhalation route.
  • Thiamine 100 mg IV injection.
  • Naloxone hydrochloride 2mg IV injection.
  • Symptomatic management for convulsions using barbiturates.

questions.text: Which lens is utilized in direct gonioscopy?
Identify the marked structure:
What is the accurate order of staining in patients with dry eyes? i. Fluorescein stain ii. Lissamine green iii. Rose Bengal stain
questions.explanation:
Investigations of dry eye

1, Slit-lamp examination
  • Superficial corneal erosions
  • Inadequate tear lake volume
  • Early tear film break-up time
  • Conjunctival hyperemia
  • Conjunctival surface irregularities
  • Meibomian gland dysfunction

2. Schirmer’s Test:
  • Schirmer’s test is used to diagnose aqueous deficiency dry eye disease.

Schirmer's Test 1

  • Measures both basal and reflex tear secretions
  • Uses Whatman-4 filter paper, kept in the lower fornix at the junction of lateral one-third and medial two-thirds.
  • After 5 minutes, wetting of the filter strip from the bent end is measured.
  • Normal value: >15 mm
  • 5-10 mm: Mild to moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS).
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

[1]

Schirmer's Test 2

  • Measures only basal secretion under anesthesia

3. Phenol Red Test
  • A modified Schirmer’s test using a cotton thread impregnated with phenol red dye.
  • The thread is placed in the lower fornix for 15 seconds.
  • Phenol dye changes from yellow to red depending on the pH of the tears.
  • Wet length: >20 mm: Normal.
  • <10 mm: Severe dry eye.
  • ≤19 mm as borderline dry eye.

4. Tear Film Break-Up Time (TBUT)
  • Tear film stained with sodium fluorescein 1% is observed under a slit lamp, and time is noted after the patient blinks.
  • The interval between the complete blink and the first appearance of a ‘dark’ dry spot on the cornea is recorded as TBUT.
  • It is an indicator of the adequacy of the mucin component of tears.
  • Normal: 15-35 seconds
  • < 10 seconds indicates unstable tear film.

5. Rose Bengal or Lissamine Green

Stain devitalized, desiccated corneal and conjunctival epithelium red or green.

 

6. Alcian Blue

Stains particulate matter in the tear film due to mucus

7. Tear Osmolarity

Increased in dry eye

8. Tear to Lysozyme ratio

Between 0.9 and 0.6 indicates dry eye.

questions.text: In the provided image, which nerve is subjected to blockage?
A patient was prescribed with -1D spherical and -2D cylindrical at 180 degrees. What type of refractive error does this patient have?
questions.explanation:
With-the-Rule Astigmatism (WTR)

Against-the-Rule Astigmatism (ATR)
  • The vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal.

 

  • Correction requires a concave cylindrical lens at 180° ± 20° or a convex cylindrical lens at 90° ± 20°.

 

  • It is called "with-the-rule" because the vertical meridian is normally more convex than the horizontal due to eyelid pressure.
  • The horizontal meridian is more curved than the vertical meridian.

 

  • Correction requires a convex cylindrical lens at 180° ± 20° or a concave cylindrical lens at 90° ± 20°.

Signs of active trachoma

Signs of cicatricial trachoma

Conjunctival signs:

Stage

Description

Image

Management

TF:

Trachomatous Inflammation- Follicular

  • The presence of five or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva
  • Active stage of trachoma
  • Antibiotics to eliminate the organism
  • Topical:
    • Tetracycline 1% or
    • Erythromycin 1%
    • Sulfacetamide
  • Systemic:
    • Tetracycline or erythromycin orally
    • Doxycycline orally
    • Azithromycin single oral dose
  • Combined systemic and topical therapy:
    • For TI or when an associated genital infection is present
    • Tetracycline 1% or erythromycin 1% eye ointment
    • Azithromycin orally

TI: Trachamatous Inflammation- Intense

Pronounced inflammatory thickening of the tarsal conjunctiva that obscures more than half of the normal deep tarsal vessels.

TS: Trachamatous Scarring

  • Presence of scarring in tarsal conjunctiva
  • White, bands or sheets of fibrosis in tarsal conjunctiva
  • Concretions removed with a hypodermic needle
  • Conjunctival xerosis with artificial tears (lubricating drops)

TT: Trachamatous Trichiasis

At least one eyelash rub on eyeball or evidence of recent removal of inturned eyelashes.
  • Permanent lash removal:
    • Electrolysis
    • Cryolysis
    • Radiofrequency epilation
    • Bilamellar tarsal resection
  • Cicatricial entropion surgery

CO: Corneal Opacity
  • Easily visible corneal opacity over the pupil
  • Part of the pupil margin is blurred when seen through the opacity as it is very dense corneal scarring
  • After treatment of other trachoma sequelae
  • Penetrating keratoplasty for significant corneal scarring
  • Keratoprosthesis for bilateral blind cases with extensive scarring and surface problems
  • Punctal occlusion and lateral tarsorrhaphy for coexistent eye surface problems

How does Total plasma exchange help in the management of TTP

options.label: A
options.text: TPE removes the Von Willebrand factor

options.label: C
options.text: TPE removes Anti ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases the ADAMTS protease activity

questions.correct_answer: C. TPE removes Anti ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases the ADAMTS protease activity
questions.explanation:
Treatment of TTP

Plasma exchange (PEX) with high-dose corticosteroid therapy.
  • It is the mainstay of treatment in TTP.
  • Corticosteroids operate by decreasing the activity of the reticuloendothelial system as well as decreasing autoantibody production.
  • Both the ultra-large VWF multimers and the ADAMTS13 autoantibodies are effectively removed from circulation by plasma exchange therapy.
  • The recommended volume of exchange is one estimated plasma volume (usually 40 mL/kg of body weight) with each treatment.
  • The recommended dose for corticosteroids is 1 mg/kg per day of prednisolone.

Rituximab

An anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody was found to help treat TTP refractory to PEX. It targets B-lymphocytes and has a good response rate in refractory and relapsed TTP.

Caplacizumab
  • It has a high potential for TTP.
  • It is a humanized monoclonal antibody fragment (a bivalent, variable-domain-only fragment) that attacks the A1 section of VWF and prevents platelet adhesion.

Others
  • Splenectomy,
  • Vincristine,
  • Cyclosporine and
  • Cyclophosphamide.

questions.explanation:
Hairy cell leukemia

Pathogenesis

Mutation of BRAF V600E gene → Activation of the BRAF protein → MAPK/ERK signalling pathway → Uncontrolled proliferation and survival of mature B-cells (Hairy cells).

Peripheral Blood Findings
  • Hairy cells with round, oblong, or reniform nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm.

Bone Marrow Biopsy Findings
  • Hypocellular or fibrotic marrow with "hairy cells".
  • Fried egg appearance.

Diagnosis
  • Flow cytometry
  • Immunophenotyping
  • Genetic testing for BRAF V600E mutation

questions.text: Match the following: A. Caplan’s syndrome 1. Found first in coal worker B. Asbestosis 2. Crazy pavement C. Mesothelioma 3. Involves lower lobe D. Silicosis 4. Pleural effusion
questions.explanation:
A. Caplan’s syndrome     
  • It is characterised by the formation of multiple well-defined pulmonary nodules, typically located in the lung periphery, in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis who have been exposed to inorganic dust.
  • It is primarily associated with coal worker's pneumoconiosis but can also occur in other forms of pneumoconiosis.

B. Asbestosis
  • It primarily affects the lower lobes of the lungs and increases the risk of laryngeal, ovarian, colon, lung, and pleural cancers, with lung cancer risk significantly heightened in smokers.
  • Asbestos-related lung carcinoma typically targets the lower lobes, unlike other occupational lung diseases that affect the upper lobes.

C. Mesothelioma
  • It is a rare cancer originating from mesothelial cells, most commonly affecting the pleura.
  • CT scan typically shows pleural thickening, effusion, or frozen hemithorax.
  • It can also involve the peritoneum, pericardium, and tunica vaginalis.

D. Silicosis
  • It is the most prevalent occupational lung disease and is caused by inhaling proinflammatory crystalline silica.
  • After decades of exposure, it typically presents as slowly progressing, nodular, fibrosing pneumoconiosis.
  • The CT scan shows a "crazy pavement" pattern and interstitial fibrosis.

questions.text: What is the commonest cause of a hypercoagulable state?
questions.explanation:
Primary causes of Hypercoagulable states

Common causes
  • Factor V mutation (Factor V Leiden)
  • Prothrombin mutation (G20210A) - It is comparatively less common than Factor V mutation (Option D ruled out)
  • Elevated factor levels (VIII, IX, XI, or fibrinogen)

Rare causes
  • Antithrombin III deficiency (Option A ruled out)
  • Protein C deficiency (Option B ruled out)
  • Protein S deficiency

Very rare causes
  • Fibrinolysis Defects
  • Homozygous Homocystinuria

Secondary causes of Hypercoagulable states

Major risk factors
  • Myocardial infarction
  • Atrial fibrillation
  • Tissue injury (surgery, fracture, burn)
  • Cancer
  • Prosthetic cardiac valves
  • DIC
  • Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
  • Prolonged rest or immobilisation

Additional risk factors for thrombosis
  • Cardiomyopathy
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Hyperestrogenic states (pregnancy and postpartum)
  • Oral contraceptive use
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Smoking

questions.text: A lady on OCPs presents with white discharge per vagina with no itching or foul smell. It stains her underwear yellow and shows normal lactobacilli with an acidic pH on examination of the discharge. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer B - Increased normal vaginal discharge

Complication

Details

Minor Complications

Nausea, Vomiting, Headache

Common initial side effects due to hormonal changes; usually resolve over time. Consider dose adjustment if persistent.

Mastalgia

Breast tenderness or pain; typically resolves within a few cycles.

Weight Gain

Minimal long-term weight gain

Menstrual Abnormalities

Includes breakthrough bleeding, hypomenorrhea, menorrhagia, and amenorrhea; often resolves with continued use.

Libido

Changes in sexual desire can occur

Leukorrhea

Increase in vaginal discharge

Major Complications

Depression

Mood changes or depression related to hormonal fluctuations

Hypertension

Elevated blood pressure; requires regular monitoring and possible medication adjustment.

Vascular Complications
  • Venous Thromboembolism (VTE): Increases risk three to fivefold, especially in those with hypertension, diabetes, obesity, or smoking.
  • Arterial Thrombosis: Increased risk of stroke and myocardial infarction

Cholestatic Jaundice

Liver dysfunction resulting in jaundice; Resolves after discontinuation of OCPs.

Neoplasia

Association with cervical cancer; regular Pap smears recommended for screening.

questions.text: The following image is obtained from a 45-year-old woman with a left ovarian mass. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Correct Answer C - Granulosa cell tumor

Granulosa Cell Tumors

Incidence
  • 70% of all ovarian sex cord tumours are granulosa cell tumors
  • 2% of all ovarian neoplasms

Types
  • Adult form (95%)
  • Juvenile form (5%)

Characteristics
  • Slow growing
  • Solid or cystic or mixed
  • The cut section shows yellow/orange due to lipid content

HPE Appearance
  • Round/polygonal cells with granular eosinophilic cytoplasm
  • Coffee bean nuclei
  • Call-Exner bodies (Pathognomonic)

 

Hormonal Activity & Markers
  • Secrete inhibin B, estrogen, and AMH

Clinical Features

  • Prior to puberty: Precocious puberty
  • Childbearing period: Abnormal uterine bleeding
  • Postmenopausal: Bleeding often with endometrial hyperplasia or adenocarcinoma

Prognosis
  • Good overall prognosis
  • The 5-year survival rate for stage I disease is about 95%
